reviewText: Rocky IV, 1985 filmIt begins with a replay of the ending of Rocky III. Rocky and Apollo enter the ring to continue the story. Rocky’s son uses a video camera. There is a new machine to add interest. Their ninth anniversary is near. Adrienne gets a present - a fancy watch. Ivan Drago is a new boxer from Russia, he will compete as a professional boxer. Will he show super-strength? Apollo wants to fight him. They watch a film of an old fight, then discuss their careers. Later there is a meeting between Ivan and Apollo; one speaks his mind. [Apollo is a stand-in for Rocky.] Is he ready for this exhibition fight? “Us against them.” We see a Las Vegas show, a singer and dancing. [Show business to distract people?]Ivan holds off at first, then shows his strength. Apollo is hit hard and goes down. “Get a doctor!” “If he dies, he dies.” Rocky makes a speech at the grave site. The press tells of another fight. This will take place in Russia. There are comments on political systems. Why did Rocky ask for this fight? Is it suicide? “You can’t win!” What can he lose? There are flashbacks to the past. [This pads out the story.] Rocky flies in an old twin propeller engine airplane. [Note the expressions on the faces.] Rocky has “official chaperones” to watch him. “Do svedanya.” This site is very isolated. Rocky will have a difficult time but will win in the end. So his trainer says. Rocky runs outdoors, Ivan trains with machines indoors. [Which is better?] Adrienne visits Rocky; she missed him. Rocky runs in the snow uphill. [Is that a stunt double on that rocky hill?] The day of the fight arrives. Rocky kneels in prayer. The fight attracts politicians.The boxers arrive for their meeting. [No testing for drugs?] They stand for a song. [More padding? That whistling is equivalent to booing.] Is it an example of David and Goliath? [Remember who won?] Punches are thrown. [Sound effects add realism.] Rocky takes a beating. “Hit the one in the middle.” Again Rocky is hit, but gets in a few punches too. The rounds continue. The audience cheers for Rocky now. Then it is the last round. Rocky wins with a knock-out! Rocky makes a speech about changing attitudes on the audience. “Everybody can change.” The people cheer. Will everybody be happy?This seems to be the worst of this series. It runs slower. That wooden house seems false; would they have tall ceilings that require extra heating? I think low ceilings are more likely in a very cold region. Was this story designed to counter-act the Cold War?

reviewText: First off, Bridgette Nielson was no great actress.  Remember her speech which she summarizes the American attitude towards Russians thusly:  "You think that YOU are so very good, and WE are so very BAD!!"Yikes!Granted, she didn't have much to work with in the way of dialogue, now did she?This is truly disenheartening when one reflects that Stallone is a good writer, both of plot and of dialogue.  "Rocky", "Rocky II", "First Blood", "Cliffhanger", and "The Lords of Flatbush" are all testaments to this fact.  So what happened?  Why the absense of good dialogue?  Where's the plot?  "Where's the beef?", to quote a colloquialism popular at the time of this film's release?Well, as Gene Siskel remarked, there was a time in Stallone's career when he devoted more energy to expanding his biceps that to writing great films.  Sadly, "Rocky IV" stands as a testament to the late Mr. Siskel's insightful observation.Granted, in a film of this nature, one can't expect too many plot surprises.  It is, after all, a film about a boxer who boxes.  Still, what made "Rocky" and "Rocky II" so compeling was Stallone's ability to add a very human story of triumph over not just external adversity, but also over one's internal feelings of worthlessness.  Both Rocky Balboa and Adrian (portrated by gifted actress Talia Shire) are shown stepping out of the roles the world would prescribe for them and instead embracing one another.  In so doing, they triumph over the worldly adversities imposed upon them.Stallone tries to re-create that in "Rocky IV", but doesn't quite make it.Why?  Because he's repeating himself.  Rocky and Adrian have already proved themselves to be worthy, respectable people.  That was accomplished by the end of "Rocky II".  To have to continually demonstrate one's worthiness is, in effect, to express doubt in exactly what it is one is seeking to prove.So, Rocky loses his best friend Apollo to a "Demonstration Bout" with Drago.  He of course seeks to avenge his fallen friend, and the rest is easy to predict.  Rocky must prove to those pesky Russians that they won't have the upper hand with us, etc.The film ends with Rocky giving a speech about change, which is something he doesn't do at all in the film, so it is difficult to see how this speech ties into the plot.To offer a few compliments to what is otherwise a bad review, let me say this: this film is beautifully photographed, and Stallone's boxing choreography is both exciting and riveting, as usual.  This, however, ultimately adds to my poor assessment of this film, in a rather ironic way.  You see, the direction and acting in the film are really quite good.  What sucks is the plot and dialogue.As Paul Newman said, "Give an actor a good script and he can move the earth".  Well, considering the level of writing these actors had to work with, I suppose they were just doing the best they could.  Even Stallone.
summary: Great direction, good acting, no plot, REALLY BAD dialogue

reviewText: Giving you a brief rundown where I stand, I thought Part 1 was pretty good; I feel Part 2 was actually a little better than Part 1; Clubber Lang dragged Part 3 down, but Apollo Creed saved it; part 4 is alright, but it doesn't match part 2; and I feel that in some ways, part 5 is the best. Well, onto the subject at hand. "Rocky IV" is by far the most commercial chapter in the saga. With Apollo's help, Rocky has regained his title and silenced Clubber Lang's big mouth. Rocky and Apollo (now retired friends) have gone back to their lives. While watching tv, Apollo notices that the Soviets have boasted of creating the ultimate boxer. (Dolph Lundgren/Ivan Drago) Apollo tells his friend Rocky that he wants to have a match with Ivan Drago. (This is understandable enough. Apollo wants to prove to himself that even though he is aging, he can still do what is important to him. Remember, Apollo is a few years older than Rocky.) Rocky reluctantly agrees to cooperate. In Part 3, Apollo was the man in Rocky's corner, and now, Rocky will be the man in Apollo's corner. (Nice switch.) The first meeting with Apollo and Ivan starts agreeable enough, but the Soviets make some uncalled for comments towards Apollo that naturally cause him to become angry and resentful. When they meet in the ring, Apollo loses the first round to the point that Rocky warns Apollo to stop the fight while he still can. Unfortunately, Apollo refuses to do so, and he is killed in the 2nd round. I know some people were upset that Apollo died in this chapter, but sadly, it makes sense. First of all, the writer had to give Rocky a reason to pull himself out of retirement and embark on a fight that will prove dangerous at best; but even moreso, Apollo's death makes literary sense. In Part 3, Rocky's trainer Mickey had to die to pave the way for Apollo to switch from Rocky's foe to his friend, trainer, and inspiration. Going a little deeper, the cycle of Apollo's character was complete. In Part 1, he was Rocky's foe, but we had no real reason to dislike him; in part 2, he was more of a villain, but the hate mail he was getting allowed us to understand his anger and frustrations; and when Rocky does beat him, he is far from a sore loser; his words to Rocky are: "Good luck." In Part 3, Apollo becomes somewhat of an older brother to Rocky in his time of need. Often people prefer to kill a well developed character once he has completed his cycle rather than dilute him. I call this the most commercial chapter because America was at the time in a cold war with the Soviet Union. After Apollo's funeral, Rocky goes through an interesting series of flashbacks, and resolves himself to go to Russia and fight Ivan Drago to avenge Apollo. Though I was forced to agree with Adrian when she said: "Even if you win, Apollo is still gone." From here, the story slips back into the pattern we are all too familiar with. As far as Rocky's opponents go, Apollo had the most depth; Clubber Lang was flat out annoying and repulsive; Ivan Drago has little if any personality. He is technically human, but he seems more like a robot who is programmed to kill. If I say anything more, I will probably ruin the movie for those of you who haven't seen it. As I suggested in my title, this 4th chapter is too commercial and predictable. John Avildsen (Director of Part 1) would return to direct Part 5, which in my opinion was much better. I know I'm in the minority opinion by saying Part 2 and Part 5 were arguably the best chapters; but I don't believe I'm in the minority when I say Part 4 is not the greatest chapter. SIDE NOTE: If you want to see a better movie with Dolph Lundgren, he was somewhat impressive in "Masters of the Universe." He was the He Man against Frank Langella's Skeletor. Granted, it wasn't exactly an over the boards smash, but at least Lundgren shows his ability as an actor more.

reviewText: Rocky Balboa is now a rich man free to do whatever he wants. The champion watches as his friend and mentor Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) announces that he will fight Ivan Drago (Dolph Lungren), a gigantic Russian amateur boxer, in an exhibition match in Las Vegas. It will be a mammoth media event - the East versus the West. It will be an opportunity for Creed to re-establish himself as a champion. He tells Rocky: "We're never gonna fit the normal life - never, 'cause we're the warriors . . . and without a war to fight, a warrior might as well be dead."When the high-tech muscleman from Russia meets Creed in the ring, he literally punches Apollo to death. Rocky resigns his championship and decides to fight Drago in Russia. Although his wife (Talia Shire) is opposed to the vengeance match, she can't dissuade him - he's a warrior and warriors must fight.So it's off to Siberia where Rocky trains in the wilderness, assisted by Paulie (Burt Young) and Creed's old right helper Duke (Tony Burton). While Drago's muscularity is measured by computers and enhanced by steroid injections, Rocks earns his strength the hard way - he chops wood, pulls carts with rocks in them, and runs up a mountain.The match is set. It's the Russian fighting machine versus the street smart American. Although Drago has the harder punches, Rocky has the heart and the endurance to win. Even the Russian people are moved by his tenacity. And, of course, all the world loves the underdog.Rocky IV is designed - as were all the other movies in this series - to move us viscerally. And that it does. Sylvester Stallone stands tall in victory, draped in the American flag - a fitting image for 1985 when citizens seem to shiver at the sight of the red, white, and blue. No wonder the box-office tallies for Rocky IV are Herculean. This movie saga seems to mirror our fondest fantasies about manhood, the fighting spirit, and patriotism.

reviewText: Move over, Reagan.  Take a seat there, Gorbachev.  After all, you guys were just politicians; we all know that the Cold War was won by none other than the Italian Stallion!  Forget the missile silos, Star Wars, and glasnost:  The 'Evil Empire' was brought to its knees by a southpaw heavyweight wearing red, white and blue trunks.  It's all documented in ROCKY IV, for cryin' out loud.In the fourth Rocky installment (this series has more sequels than my car payment coupon book) we find Rocky blissfully content in the twilight of his boxing career.  He's got it all:  great family, mansion, wealth, even a talking robot.  Enter a genetic mutant fighting machine from the Soviet Union--exit ex-champ Apollo Creed, who bites the canvas during a rather nasty exhibition match.  What's left to do?  Why, challenge the chiseled Ivan Drago to a boxing match in Mother Russia, of course!  And while Drago trains with state-of-the-art, high-tech gismo equipment, Rocky trains in a barn and a couple of snowdrifts in Siberia.Works for me.  Sort of.Then it's showdown time, in Moscow, on Christmas Day, in front of a hostile, snarling crowd.  Drago is twice Rocky's size, while the American fighter goes through fifteen rounds of imitating a bobble-head doll.  But. . .in the end. . .there's no overcoming the heart of a champion.  And then, a rousing speech--for peace.Bring down the Berlin Wall.ROCKY IV is a syrupy flick that entertains while simultaneously making the viewer wish Sly Stallone had quit this series while it possessed even a shred of credibility.  Talia Shire mopes and cries, Burt Young is as annoying as ever, and Carl Weathers becomes a superficial caricature of his once-great Apollo Creed character.  Dolph Lundgren and Brigitte Nielsen obviously had the same barber.  But hey, the Cold War's over:  now if we could just get Rocky to go to France.--D. Mikels

The movie goes through the familiar Rocky sequence of adversity to inspiration to training to boxing, but even on the fourth go-round it is still entertaining and not cloying.  The movie's soundtrack yielded three Top 40 hits.It was on Christmas Day six years after the movie was released that Mikhail Gorbachev resigned--he was the last head of state of the Evil Empire, which went on the ash heap of history the following day.  "Rocky IV" seemed topical in 1985, but seems so dated now, very much including the cheesy mid-Eighties background music during the training sessions.  Still, the film is an entertaining Cold War period movie that teaches loyalty to friends and love of country.

reviewText: From the time of its original release, Rocky 4 was maligned for one reason-its uninhibited, completely unapologetic flag-waving. Most critics are Liberals. Now, I don't hate Liberals, but let's face it, if there's anything they hate worse than flag-waving, it's machismo. So this was simply never going to be their movie.Of course, the nationalistic elements ARE there, and they are obvious. But this is, first and foremost, a story about MEN. The macho swagger of Apollo Creed, the repressed rage of Drago, the iron will and inherent decency of Rocky. THESE are the things that make the film what it is. This movie came out in 1985, but Apollo's attitude seems so contemporary. The man is a born showman, and he simply cannot abide the obscurity of retirement. But he is also a warrior at heart, and it is this combination of traits that set the story in motion.This is a truly great movie. And the death scene of Apollo Creed is one of the greatest moments in American cinema.Some have said that Stallone made this film too different from the others in the series. But I think that this was among its greatest strengths. You take a man like Rocky, who is, at heart, a quiet family man.........then you catapult him into the middle of this Cold War melodrama. He is, at once, out of place, and yet completely at home. At the press conference, and arguing with his wife, he is clearly in an emotional place that is new territory for him.But the moment he begins his training in the wintry forests of Russia, he is completely in his element.That is another of the movie's greatest virtues.......the training montage. Probably the greatest thing of its sort ever made. That scene where he is straining with all his might to pull that sled that is loaded with rocks(in an interview, Stallone said that it was about 1200 pounds worth of stones). For any man who has ever found himself thriving on a challenge, that moment just speaks to something in your soul. There is something almost metaphorical about it.Lifting that wagon, that contains 3 fully grown adults(the strain so immense, his chest resembles an array of steel cables that appear ready to burst from his frame at any second).........taking down enormous trees with powerful blows from his axe.........performing chinups with greater ease than most of us have brushing our teeth.........running up the side of that mountain.........Anybody who is familiar with Stallone knows that he uses weight training to tailor his physique for each individual film. And it never worked more to his advantage than it did here. Back in the 80's, Stallone trained like a professional bodybuilder, but ate much more conservatively. This produced the ultimate hero's body, because he was incredibly developed but not as enormous as a competitive bodybuilder. It gave him the best of both worlds..........he looked superhuman, and yet could still play the underdog. That is a rare combination.The fight itself is a bit overblown, in my estimation. It starts out great, for the first two rounds.But with both men hitting so hard, it's kind of difficult to imagine the thing actually going fifteen rounds. And the last 5 minutes of the film have a kind of aimless feel about them, as if Stallone was just ready to get the thing over with.But these are minor considerations. The good FAR outweighs the bad. This is a great film, one of Stallone's finest moments. He has lots of old-Hollywood screen presense. The man can carry a film in a way that few others could match. There is just an energy, and a power, about him. He exudes something primal, and yet something that is extremely civilized, extremely decent, and this combination serves to set him apart from most other film 'stars.'Apollo's tragic bid to hold onto his fading celebrity.........the awesome spectre of the iron-fisted Drago........Rocky's heartwrenching personal dilemma........the ADDITIONAL conflict that comes from the political dimension of the story..........these elements comprise a truly epic, immortal tale.

reviewText: It's 1985, as the decades-long Cold War may be at last coming to an end soon.  Leave it to Sylvester Stallone to offer up the implausible concept of "The Italian Stallion" facing off against the world's latest boxing terror: a seemingly invincible Russian super-man, Ivan Drago (Dolph Lundgren) to avenge his best friend's death.  That's it; the entire plot of "Rocky IV" has just been spelled out in one sentence.  This probably explains why "IV" has the franchise's shortest running time at just barely over 90 minutes.  Unless the plot was otherwise inexplicably left on the cutting room floor this time, Stallone's entire movie revolves around Rocky miraculously winning the Cold War in the boxing ring.  Yet, surprisingly, this idea actually works (sort of).With the fourth (and, yes, most popular) installment, Sylvester Stallone stumbles into the screenwriting rut of killing off an important supporting character in each new film to generate an emotionally dramatic plot.  It worked so well in "Rocky III" with the heart-breaking death of Mickey (Burgess Meredith), so this time Stallone would target the now-expendable Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers).  Apollo's death wasn't absolutely necessary, but at least his glorious (but brutal) demise is given a full-blown spectacle complete with a cameo by singer James Brown performing Apollo's new theme song, "Living in America."  Still, if Apollo had survived only to be crippled for life, it could have set up an intriguing sub-plot rectifying Apollo's possible resentment at Rocky's success down the road in "Rocky V" or even "Rocky Balboa."  For whatever reason, Stallone instead opted for a movie-length, depth-free "Rocky" music video this time.This fourth film follows the same basic pattern as "Rocky III" in terms of a fast-paced storyline (far less plot, this time) and, as I alluded to, an even greater reliance on extended musical montages (presumably, to help pad the running time).  With so little story, "IV" primarily suffers from a lack of any stand-out performances, particularly from stellar regulars Talia Shire, Tony Burton, and Burt Young (although they each have an occasional shining moment).  Lundgren's literal one-note performance consists of lines like "I must break you!" and lots of scowling.  Future Stallone spouse Brigitte Nielsen fares only slightly better as Drago's wife.  Still, if there is a MVP award for best acting here, it belongs to the underrated, charismatic Carl Weathers for making the most of his limited screen time.  The bottom line is that "Rocky IV" was not designed as an acting showcase; rather, the classy acting talent upgrades another of Stallone's fired-up machismo movies that began with "Rocky III" and the ultra-violent "Rambo" franchise.Yet, what is it that makes "Rocky IV" watchable?  It is more than just Stallone smugly knowing what "easy money" buttons to push with moviegoers.  The answer (or the button, I suppose) is the film's presumably sincere efforts at not just inspiring but igniting a timeless sense of feel-good patriotism, especially during the overblown finale.  "Top Gun" the following year would make a similar pop culture impact, but "Rocky IV" has something more to say that transcends the hateful, global politics of Us vs. Them.  As a victorious but transformed Rocky announces to the transfixed Russian audience: "If I can change ... and you can change, then everybody ... can change!"  No said it better than Rocky Balboa.Rating: 6/10 (Despite its numerous flaws, this movie still remains very watchable, and its highly energized soundtrack is superb.)
summary: "Rocky IV": The Italian Stallion Takes on the Cold War

Clubber Lang was "too strong" for Rocky to overcome with mere punching power. He had too be faster, more agile and more cunning.But with Drago... supposedly two to three times stronger than the average heavyweight... reviewText: "Rocky IV" is entertaining and fun, though I won't defend it too strongly against those who rail against it for being silly, unrealistic, etc., etc.  After all, the superhero movies of the past few years (such as the "Spider-Man" and "X-Men" films) have more subtlety, introspection, and serious themes than this movie about a boxer, a profession that actually exists!Still, despite its broadness (revenge, patriotism, and self-confidence are the simple buttons the movie is happy to repeatedly push) and simplicity of plot (two fights scenes, a couple of training sessions, an inspirational speech or two and some comic relief stuff are basically it here), "Rocky IV" DOES work.  It works because the broad, cartoony stuff is EFFECTIVE broad, cartoony stuff, and it also works because the series' heart is still in the right place.  Vanity scenes aside (the movie lovingly details every inch of Rocky's pumped-up body during the training sessions), Rocky is still a nice guy who wants to do the right thing.  For example, though revenge is certainly an element here, Rocky's fight with Drago seems to be more about honoring Apollo Creed's memory than exacting revenge for his death.But even though I enjoyed the inspirational superheroics of "Rocky IV", I'm glad that Mr. Stallone didn't continue in the same direction with "Rocky V".  If so, that movie probably would have featured Rocky battling space aliens. Instead, the next sequel featured the welcome return of a more realistic storyline set in the streets of Philadelphia.  So, knowing that the series eventually put the brakes on the ridiculous stuff, you can sit back for now with "Rocky IV" and enjoy the entertaining goofiness of Rocky Balboa bringing down communism in Soviet Russia.
summary: Who needs a pumped-up military to defend freedom when a pumped-up Rocky will do the trick?

reviewText: To say that Rocky IV is propaganda is a bold understatement. From the opening bell of Rocky IV we are fed repeated anti-soviet and pro-US messages. The obvious arrogance, rampant drug use and lack of freedoms the Russians display here are not antagonistic as much as they are downright degrading and completely inaccurate. Every Soviet character acts as if they are a pathetically corrupt villain, that is until they are shown the path of the righteous man by our hero Rocky Balboa both in and out of the ring in a shameless speech that shows us what this film is really about.  The Russian people find their liberation in their love for the American underdog Rocky.  Rocky III had a subtle message of money spoiling good ol' Rock into losing his title and regaining it when he found the fire that existed in being a real underdog (a poor New Yorker who had nothing but his ability to fight). Rock IV gives us a message that is the antithesis of this and gives blind justification for hating our enemies for trivial and inaccurate reasons, in other words the legacy of Rocky took more than a few steps back.In this, the third sequel to the original classic about a kid from south Philly who gets a shot at the champion Appollo Creed.  By now in the series, Rock has been champion and is friends now with Apollo and when Ivan Drago (a giant Russian boxer played by Dolph Lundgren) comes along, Apollo comes out of retirement to show this commie who is boss.  Drago beats him to death in the ring and Rocky now knows what he needs to do.  Stop commies!  I mean, avenge his friend's death.Its amusing to say the least as now the U.S.S.R. is no more and the damages of misled messages are inconsequential as the only people who could be swayed by such nonsense have already been swayed by our culture. It's vexing indeed but Rocky IV wins me over because I laugh every time it's on television. That is no reason to call it a good movie though. It so shamelessly sets the stage for the ultimate in melodrama and underdog cliches that only a child would find this believable. It is pornographic propaganda really, I put it right in there with Reefer Madness.As a character, Rocky does represent something of America in all of his films (though I haven't seen the fifth one entirely). He is the quintessential underdog; he is a simple man that made his way through life by being a good person and doing what he knew how to do for his family.  That feels like America for many of us. On the other hand he represents us as well in a different light in Rocky IV; he is the shameless symbol that represents what blind nationalism and unregulated globalization can bring without justifying it's reason, by the film's end the Russians are as blindly proud as the American's who possess unconditional love for their ever-serving government. It doesn't represent the left or the right but simply put, it represents those who can't learn because they think they already know.  It represents the ignorant and just plain stupid and who could be their hero, or as Mr. T. once said, their paper champion. There are means and ends in life and conflict is the means to serve what end? Rocky IV promotes the kind of thought that is too arrogant to bother answering such a question.But you know something? It's so shameless, unintentional, and fun that I don't give a damn and I begin chanting "Rocky" (or was it "Bocky") right along side those newly allied ex-communists every single time I see Rocky IV.  Capitalism rocks comrade!

reviewText: This is Stallone's pop-lit take on the Cold War.  It is significant in that it give us a feel of what a Joe Sixpack thought about Russia, especially during that critical time before Gorbachev came to power.Although it is to be expected, I found the movie to be a bit shallow.  The setting (which was obvious to us who were cognizant at the time) overshadowed the other aspects of the story.  So much time was devoted to the two montage sequences, and the Rocky-Apollo relationship that Adrian was snubbed.  Although her acting was superb, the writers gave her a part that could have been played by a cardboard cutout of Talia Shire.The worst moment was Drago's comments as Creed is dying: "If he dies, he dies." This characterization is so flat, even Filmation could not do something that bad.  What would have been better would have been for Drago to express his condolences, and offer to donate blood if necessary.  Maybe even kiss Apollo.This would be more effective, since we all know that Drago would be lying. As the Manifesto says, "Law, morality, religion, are to him so many bourgeois prejudices, behind which lurk in ambush just as many bourgeois interests. . . . The Communists disdain to conceal their views and aims. They openly declare that their ends can be attained only by the forcible overthrow of all existing social conditions."This move was effective in two areas.  The first is with the two montage scenes. The first one reminds us that this movie is part of a series--there is no rebooting or retconning to feed the fancy of the writers. The other montage--the parallel regimens--shows how Americans see the world.  We believe the more rustic and natural approach is better than science. As Jefferson wrote to Peter Carr, "He who made us would have been a pitiful bungler, if he had made the rules of our moral conduct a matter of science. . . . State a moral case to a ploughman and a professor. The former will decide it as well, and often better than the latter, because he has not been led astray by artificial rules."The second area has to do with two scenes that "show, don't tell" the difference between the US and the USSR.  The rather annoying robot is really a Transformer: more than meets the eye.  You could see an American or a Japanese having a household robot like that, but not a Soviet.The other scene is the James Brown music sequence.  Drago's reaction to the tacky glitz and glamour that is quintessentially Las Vegas reinforces the difference between East and West.  Having gone to Russia in 1992, several months after the Soviet Union collapsed, there is absolutely no why that any Soviet could come up with the music, lights, dance and showgirls that we see in this sequence.  Despite any flaws that the US has, you cannot deny the system works to the point were we can spend our surplus in this debauchery.The ending s as sappy as it is sentimental, but it shows that Americans have a desire to reconcile.  Now, two decades later, we can see that it is almost working out.  Love, Viktor Yushchenko and Alexander Litvinenko.

reviewText: While I found Rocky III an entertaining movie, I felt this was the film that began the decline of the Rocky series.  For one thing, it lost its Philadelphia focus.  There were no scenes filmed in Philadelphia.  Rocky was no longer a down and out, Philadelphia guy - but now a polished champion who had his face fixed up.  However, I think the biggest problem with Rocky III is that Rocky was beginning to get transformed into a quasi-Superhero.  He was going up against the likes of Thunderlips and Clubber Lang.  In both of these opponents, Stallone would over-choreograph the fight sequences and created some non-realistic fight scenes.  When Rocky IV was released, I was really hoping that Stallone would find a way to "go back to basics" with the Rocky series.  Instead, Stallone deviates even further from the basics and creates what I feel is the weakest of all of the Rocky movies.The story goes like this.  At the end of Rocky III, Apollo Creed told Rocky he owed him a favor.  That favor would turn out to be that Rocky would help Apollo launch a comeback.  It turns out there is a up and coming Russian fighter named Ivan Drago who is a complete physical specimen.  Apollo feels he can beat the Russian and agrees to fight him in an exhibition match.  The exhibition match turns out to be deadly - Apollo is beaten badly by Drago and dies.  Rocky is now depressed and feels he now must avenge Apollo's death in the ring.  Adrian is completely against the match, but Rocky forges ahead and agrees to fight Drago in Moscow.  Rocky will take Paulie and Apollo's trainer Tony to Siberia to train in the harshest and primitive conditions.  This contrasts to the high tech environment that Drago is fighting in.  This leads to the movie's finale which is a bloody confrontation in the ring between Rocky and Drago pitting East vs. West.There are a lot of problems with this movie.  For starters, in the mid 1980s, Sylvester Stallone seemed to have this obsession with going up against the Russians.  He had used this theme in his "Rambo" movies and now was trying to create the same theme in the Rocky movies - this just didn't belong in the series.  I also didn't like the fact how (most of the movie), the Russians were portrayed as the bad guys.  Another problem is that the storyline almost reads like a storyline in a Wrestling Pay-Per View event:  Just substitute Apollo, Rocky, and Drago as Wrestlers - Drago does something bad to Apollo,  Rocky now must extract revenge in the squared circle against Drago.Another thing that I don't like is that Apollo had to die in this movie.  By having Apollo die, another core character to the Rocky series was now gone.  In Rocky III, I felt it was a bad decision to kill off one of the more popular characters - Mickey.  Mickey provided some of the great moments in the first two Rocky movies.  While I don't think Apollo was nearly as popular as Mickey, Apollo's character was re-invented in Rocky III.  Apollo went from the villain in Rocky I/II to good guy in Rocky III.  This allowed Apollo's character to be redefined and go in new directions.  Was it really necessary to have Apollo die?The first three Rocky movies did a great job at developing the characters - especially of Rocky, Adrian, Paulie, and Apollo.  For this movie, there is virtually no character development whatsoever.  Adrian, who had grown from shy girl to strong woman in the first three movies basically doesn't change much in terms of her strength in this movie.  Paulie actually began to regress in Rocky III.  After Paulie got arrested in Rocky III, he was basically relegated to the role of cantankerous curmudgeron.  In Rocky IV, he basiclaly maintains this role.  I did find the scenes between Paulie and the Robot and Paulie in Siberia amusing, but there isn't much to growing Paulie's character.  One thing Paulie does continue to do is maintain a great sense of humor.There are some new characters introduced - namely Drago, his wife Ludmilla (played by Stallone's real-life wife at the time, Brigitte Nielson), and their "promoter" Nicoli Koloff. There is little in providing good insight into these characters.  Ludmilla acts merely as a "spokesperson" for Drago throughout the movie.  We don't see much interaction between Drago or Ludmilla and don't get a chance to see how the fight with Rocky is affecting the two as a couple.  I also felt that Nicoli's character could have been so much more.  Michael Pataki, who played Nicoli is an actor who has been around for a while.  Pataki might best remembered for his role as "Count Mallachi" in the Demolition Derby on the Pinky Tuscadero episodes on "Happy Days".  Pataki had done a great job in those episodes as well as in many other acting roles.  However, in "Rocky IV" it just seems like they never tapped Pataki's potentialAnother overall problem is the use of the music.  In Rocky III, Stallone had moved away from the passionate music of Bill Conti toward more of pop music (namely Survivor).  In Rocky IV, while there is no Bill Conti and he does continue the pop music trend, he does introduce us to a talented musician named Vince DiCola - who provides some passionate music.  The problem is that the music isn't used to compliment the movie.  Instead many of the scenes of the movie read more like a glorified music video instead of a story.  The music is good, but it could have complimented the story better.While this movie does entertain, I think this is the weakest entry in the Rocky Series.  Even the highly criticized Rocky V built up the characters and used the music much more effectively.  Still if you are a Rocky fan, you probably won't overlook this movie.
summary: The Weak Spot in the Rocky Series

reviewText: ROCKY IV, billed as East meets West, is a pretty good action film from the 1980s.  That doesn't mean it's a good Rocky movie as far as dramatic or Oscar worthy issues go, but it is one of those films you think of when you think of classic 1980s movies.This time around, Rocky must fight Ivan Drago, a fighter from the USSR.  Not only that, he must fight Drago in Russia itself for the climactic fight.Ivan Drago comes to fight for the pride of Russia.  He has an intense training schedule, and his charecteriation is over-the-top, catoonish, more fantasy than reality.  Drago is unstoppable it appears.  Apollo fights him (in attempts to regain something of a career) and is killed.  So when Rocky decides to fight him, he must fight for not only his own national pride, but for his life and the honour of his friend as well.The film very much focuses the differing contrast between Russia and America.  Prime examples of this is the opening sequences for the two main fights that occur in the film.The first fight features Apollo Creed, reprised again by Carl Weathers, against Drago.  Now Creed is pretty desperate to get back into the spotlight, and he takes an exhibition match against Drago to help propel his fighting career and to get his name out there again among the fans.  To start the fight, Drago is alone on the stage in an underground area.  The stage is then raised up from the lower pit into the ground floor of the arena.  Then James Brown (the king of soul) begins to sing an over-the-top number called "Living in America", and Apollo Creed enters the arena from high above.  The whole sequence is an exercise in how gaudy and excessive Americans can get.  There are backup singers, dancers, big lights, and Apollo in his rather tacky red, white, and blue themed suit with a large hat.  The whole sequence leaves one with a bad taste of the worst of Las Vegas.  Very tacky.Now, contrast that too the fight in Russia, where every one is reserved, and the fight is before Russian national leaders who are in attendance, as wella s the general crowd.  A large billboard or flag is unfurled with Drago's image, but everyone is respectiful.  It's a totally different atmosphere.The second is the training.  Drago is treated like a machine.  All of his training is closely monitored via machinery and state-of-the-art monitoring equipment.  Rocky, on the other hand, trains naturally in the Russian mountains.  The training montage in this film is probably my favorite of the six Rocky films, as Drago's training is just so over the top compared to Rocky's.  Then we get the immortal scene in which Rocky climbs a mountain ridge, and in an impressive panoramic shot of him high up on this mountain change he yells "DRAGO!!!!!", like he's ready to fight right then and there.I can understand why people who are fans of the first two films (which are quite similar enough to be regard as two halves, almost) express disappointment in ROCKY III and IV.  III is classic 1980s cheese, especially the fight with "Thunderlips" Hulk Hogan.  Still, there is some dramatic tension in III (most of these scenes, tellingly enough, involve Burgess Meredith as Mickey).IV, however, is so far removed from the gritty street drama of the first two films as to be unrecognizable.  The characters are not nearly as narrowly defined as they are here.  There's a lot of character and heart in ROCKY.  In ROCKY IV, Stallone changes Rocky from being a very real, good hearted guy to being little more than the latest action movie hero.  The characterization isn't nearly as strong in this movie as in the other Rocky films, and they're much more simplified.  It also has the whole aging question where Rocky questions if he's too old to fight (strangely enough this question has been debated by Rocky since the very first film).  And the robot that Paulie gets is really over the top.  Who the hell wrote that into the script, Stallone?The worst part about ROCKY IV is the very end.  Even though Drago is apparently unstoppable, a superhuman god, and even killed Apollo pretty easily, somehow he beats the hell out of Rocky but Rocky still comes out victorious.And then we get to the most heinous, ridiculous moment in Stallone's career.  The "We can change" speech.Now remember, ROCKY IV came out in 1985, when Russina/US relationships were at a breaking point.  There was trouble on the international front.  And then we get this piece of tripe.During the course of the fight, the Russian people go from actively hostile toward Rocky to chanting his name.  Rather ridiculous, given the political climate of the time, but whatever.  Then the Russian leaders give Rocky a standing ovation.  Then we get to the most sentimental tripe Stallone ever had the bad graces to write.Basically, Rocky says that he's changed, and so did the Russians in their attitude toward him.  Then, in one big feel good moment, he yells "We can all change!"  Yeah, like a single fight between Rocky and Drago will change international politics forever.As gaudy and tacky as the Las Vegas intro of Apollo Creed is in comparison to the Russian fight at the end of the movie, the same analogy could be said of ROCKY IV in comparison to ROCKY.  ROCKY deserves an Oscar.  ROCKY IV is nothing but an action flick with cartoon fighters.That being said, don't think I don't like the movie.  It's a great movie.  Lots of fun, very 1980s.  Watching it just takes you back to earlier times in your life.  It's not nearly dramatically compelling or nearly good as the original ROCKY.  But then again, it doesn't have to be.  It's a much different film from the first.  It can get cheesy at times, but it's one of those essential movies anyone who grew up in the 1980s must see.
summary: Even more 1980s than ROCKY III, Rocky apparently has the answer on foreign policy between USSR and USA

Apollo Creed is in denial that he is getting old and is no longer the great boxer he once was and wants to step into the ring against the much younger Russian to prove he still has what it takes as a pugilist. reviewText: The original "Rocky" was a quiet, thoughtful, warm and wonderful movie; an American classic, well-deserving of the 1976 Best Picture Oscar it won.  The story took us inside a small and believable world within the city of Philadelphia, and introduced us to a group of real, down-to-earth human beings.  "Rocky II" and "Rocky III" were fun and enjoyable sequels, not in the same class as the original but true to the characters we had come to know and care about.  "Rocky IV", while written and directed (unbelievably) by the same Sylvester Stallone, went so far off the rails into fantasyland that...well, where to begin? (Spoiler Alert)First it's Paulie's birthday and he gets a girl-robot (huh?!!) from Rocky and Adrian.  Then we meet Ivan Drago, who may as well be the Incredible Hulk.  So Apollo comes out of retirement (with a little help from James Brown) to fight Drago, who kills him in the ring.  Rocky then goes to Russia for a revenge rematch, but he's not quite sure of himself until (of course) Adrian shows up with words of encouragement.  Finally the big fight, in which Rocky takes enough of a beating to topple Godzilla but ultimately beats the invincible Drago while the Russian crowd chants "Rocky! Rocky!"  Finally, Rocky grabs the microphone and starts giving a political speech about how the US and Russia need to stop hating each other!By the end of this film, I couldn't even recognize the characters from the original.  They had been turned into comic book versions of themselves.  And I kept hoping that in the final scene, Rocky would wake up back in Philadelphia and proceed to tell Adrian about this crazy dream he just had.

reviewText: When former boxer Apollo Creed sees a Russian fighter named Ivan Drago on televison getting all sorts of hype, Creed gets offended given all the tension that is going on between the U.S.A. and Russia, and he feels Drago is trying to make the States look bad.Apollo Creed has always been a charismatic, patriotic, and loveable showman who loves to entertain people and express his patriotism. He is also someone who loves to get attention, and take risks, so retirement has been a rough adjustment for him. He feels empty inside and he needs to have just one more match, so he has an idea to strike back against the Russians, defend the honor of the United States of America, and get some closure for himself.....Back in the old days when there were two tribes feuding with one another, each tribe would send it's greatest warrior out to face the other and end the dispute, and since Rocky has no interest in facing Drago, Apollo volunteers.It has been five years since Apollo last boxed, but Apollo feels confident that he can defeat Drago who he describes as being clumsy. Apollo asks Rocky for help. Rocky is hesitant at first since they know nothing about Drago, but since Apollo helped Rocky out once when facing an enemy in the ring, Rocky feels he owes his friend, and agrees to help train Apollo.Creed comes out of retirement, and challenges Drago to a friendly exhibition match in Las Vegas, Nevada, which Drago accepts.The big match happens, and Apollo makes a big entrance just like he did during the first fight with Rocky back in 1976. Drago cluelessly stands in the middle of the ring, watching it all, and wondering what exactly he has walked into.As the bell rings, things do not go over well for Apollo. He is clearly out of practice, and he experiences some ring rust. Drago's trainers see Apollo's weakness, and they instruct Drago to launch an all out assault on him, and Drago delivers several powerful punches to Apollo, and he gives him no time to ease himself in, and loosen himself up. Creed is surprised to learn Drago is a very strong, and ruthless fighter, and Apollo has no plan to combat Drago's vicious assault.This leads to Rocky challenging Drago to a match to avenge his friend, and his country, much to Rocky's wife, Adrian's disapproval. Drago accepts the challenge, but the boxing commission will not sanction Rocky's fight with Ivan Drago, and Rocky is forced to relinquish the title.The fight is scheduled to take place in Russia, so Rocky goes there, along with his friend and brother-in-law, Paulie, and Apollo's long-time trainer, Tony Duke, to a secluded ranch house in a farming community out in the snowy rural country of Russia to temporally live with a farmer, so Rocky can train around the area with as much privacy as he can get, which leads to some AWESOME training montages with some very beautiful scenery, and a great soundtrack.Sly Stallone already told a dramatic and romantic story about Rocky with the first few films, so I think it's cool he did something new and different with this one. This Rocky film is more like an action movie then a drama. It feels distant from the first Rocky movie, which makes sense since Rocky is in a foreign country, and out of his element. The Cold War is going on in this story, and Rocky IV is a hybrid of the Rocky films, and a war film.I think some people go into this movie expecting it to be like the first one, but I believe in order to enjoy this film, you have to see it for what it is - A movie about the Cold War. The battlefield is inside the boxing ring, and there's no guns or bombs. Just fists, and who has the stronger will.While the first few Rocky movies were about proving to the world that he's not just another bum from the neighborhood, this movie is about friendship, patriotism, and loyalty to your friends, family, and your home.I think Rocky IV is a great movie. It's a good popcorn and soda film, it's very entertaining, funny, action-packed, emotional, and it has a wonderful soundtrack. It's also a good movie to watch around winter time. All and all, it's a classic fish out of water/culture clash/war movie, and a great and fun 1980's film. If you like the other Rocky movies, sports films,  and/or 1980's action films, I believe you'll enjoy Rocky IV. I should also add Rocky IV looks GREAT in HD. So if you have an HDTV, a blu-ray player, and surround sound, you're in for a treat.
summary: "Let us not be deceived. We are today in the midst of a cold war." - Bernard Baruch

reviewText: Rocky IV (1985) is a movie that carries a great message of keeping one's mind open to change in a turbulent Cold War. Yes, this is a political message, and one that unfortunately crept into a sports film, but that was the climate in the 1980's. While I'm accepting of this approach, this film nonetheless manages to disappoint in other areas. For example, Rocky isn't the same person he was in the streets of Philadelphia in Rocky I and II, as he's become rich; he speaks well, dresses well, and manages to own a very annoying robot. This new image of Rocky has viewers like me screaming, because that's not who he really is, though Rocky himself alludes to the fact that material things don't change everything. Furthermore, Rocky's opponent is the ridiculously huge Ivan Drago, who is more like a wrestler than a boxer. It's a tough sell for the audience to believe that Balboa can defeat someone who literally killed his previous opponent, Apollo Creed. Yes, Rocky has heart and determination, but it seems a bit unrealistic to see him defeat an opponent who's so much bigger and powerful. Overall, Rocky IV is a decent movie that surprisingly gets to the point (at only 90 minutes). It was weird seeing Apollo challenging Drago in one scene, then the very next scene has him fighting Drago. Whatever. Hmmm........I also miss the hard-drinking foul-mouthed Pauly, who seems refined in this film. To sum up, Rocky IV is a film depicting hope, heartache, fame, and fortune. 6/10

reviewText: In the pantheon of Rocky films, this fourth installment has received both high praise and much malignment.  It seems as if you either love it or hate it, with no middle ground.  To me, this film not only succeeds, but succeeds on two different levels: Cold War analogy, and present-day boxing environment.For a basic plot summary, "Rocky IV" sees former champion Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) trying to make a comeback against the freakishly large Russian newcomer Ivan Drago (Dolph Lundgren).  When Creed fails in the attempt to win the East-West battle, the task falls to Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone).The first level this film succeeds on is the Cold War analogy.  This theme obviously played much better in 1985, but it still resonates to this day.  It works because, on only one occasion (in Rocky's final speech), does it descend into sappiness.  Otherwise, it tries not to make too much of a political statement.However, if you don't buy into the Cold War angle, this movie still holds up well as a mirror of the current boxing culture.  With the Klitschko brothers ruling the heavyweight division with their powerful blows that mask their glass chins (just like Drago), they have booted any American challengers from the top spots.  This is probably just a lucky coincidence on director Stallone's part, but perhaps he can be given some credit for a bit of foresight.Overall, this is a film that CAN be enjoyed, despite the objections of many.  It takes a bit more suspension of reality than its predecessors to enjoy, but if you can buy in to the drama and spectacle, you will be cheering when the credits roll.
summary: Is It East vs. West...Or Man Against Man?

And not only does that pseudo-music-video montage of snippets from the previous "Rocky"s attract the MTv generation, it also helps those slower moviegoers & folks who missed the previous installments get back up to speed.
